newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia says forces ready for space probe crash.
newsitem.headline: Australia says forces ready for space probe crash.

text.p: Australian Prime Minister John Howard said on Monday Australian defence forces had been asked to prepare for an emergency after the possible impact of a stricken Russian space probe which could hit Australia later in the day.

Howard told reporters Russian authorities had advised Canberra that four lethal plutonium canisters on board were designed to withstand the heat of re-entry and impact on the ground. "In which case, there would be no danger of contamination," he said.
"I chaired a meeting of the national security council this morning which has asked the Australian defence force ... to make preparations to deal with any emergency."

The probe contains reinforced canisters containing 200 grammes of plutonium that pose a lethal threat if they crack open. Howard said the United States had offered assistance in dealing with the canisters if they were to split open.

White House press secretary Mike McCurry earlier issued a statement saying the U.S. "believes the size of the probe is large enough to give pieces of it a chance of surviving re-entry, though most of the space craft will burn up in the atmosphere".
